3353149648.resolved_title:
How to Save an Ancient Language Before It 
Disappears Forever
3353149648.excerpt:
It’s 6:30 p.m. at a radio studio in Miaoli, a small city
 in Western Taiwan. Yin Chang is plugged in. Her headphones are on, and 
the microphone is adjusted close to her mouth. The lights are dim; a 
blue banner declaring “Voice of Hakka Radio 97.1 FM” hangs behind her.

1.credit:
Photo courtesy of DJ 
Yin Chang
1.caption:
At the 97.1 FM Hakka radio station, DJ Yin 
Chang runs “Henai,” an evening Hakka language program, and 
“Multivitamin,” a night Mandarin language program aimed at youth. As a 
DJ, Chang works to promote the Hakka language, Hakka music and rising 
Hakka musicians.

2.caption:
Hakka artists weave a basket in the traditional Hakka 
style. However, to modernize the craft, they use plastic strips rather 
than wood splints.

3.caption:
The 
College of Hakka Studies at National Chiao Tung University is located in
 Hsinchu in northwestern Taiwan. With 69.5 percent of the population 
being Hakka, Hsinchu is the county with the highest concentration of 
Hakka people in Taiwan.

4.caption:
Baiwei Lin, 23, poses in front of her desk at the College
 of Hakka Studies at National Central University. Inspired by her Hakka 
identity, Lin is a graduate student in the program. She is currently 
focusing her research on Meinung, an area in southern Taiwan with a 
large concentration of Hakka people.

5.caption:
Henzung Zhang, 90, flips through the pages of a Hakka 
dictionary he worked on for ten years. The dictionary is currently used 
by Hakka language teachers and at Hakka cultural centers. He wrote the 
dictionary in hopes of teaching Hakka to younger generations more 
accurately, as primary schools are now required to teach mother 
languages, including Hakka.

6.caption:
Zhang and his grandson visit a Hakka quadrangle of a 
family friend and sit at the center shrine. Hakka quadrangles are 
similar to Beijing’s quadrangles or courtyard houses. However, Hakka 
quadrangles are enclosed by buildings on three sides rather than four. 
The center room is a shrine for venerating ancestors.

 object of inquiry in linguistics is human language, in particular the

3321961586.given_title:
What the sound of your name says about you - BBC 
Future
3321961586.resolved_title:
What the sound of your name says
 about you
3321961586.excerpt:
Picture two cartoon characters, one round and the other 
spiky. Which would you name Bouba, and which one, Kiki? And which do you
 then think is more outgoing? Perhaps surprisingly, most of you will 
probably attribute the same name and characteristics to each of the 
shapes.

1.caption:
People tend to consider the 
sound of the letter 'i' as spiky while 'o' has a much rounder shape in 
the mouth

2.caption:
The word prickly is as spiky as
 it sounds, and such associations can help when learning languages

3.caption:
Rounder, smoother-sounding 
names like Molly tend to be associated with being agreeable

4.caption:
The way a word feels in your 
mouth as you say it can trigger some surprising psychological 
reactions

Linguistic Divide Between An
623886566.resolved_title:

 to Bridge the Linguistic Divide Between Animals and Humans
623886566.excerpt:
While captive in a Navy program, a beluga whale named 
Noc began to mimic human speech. What was behind his attempt to talk to 
us? Millions of years before we humans came along, the earth’s oceans 
were a vast, unbroken web of whale song.

3.caption:
Sam Ridgway deployed whales in the Navy Marine Mammal 
Program. “They come to think of us as family,” he says. “And that’s the 
reason they stay with  us.”

5.caption: Navy harbor-patrol sea lion, San Diego.

6.caption: Dolphin marking a practice mine, undisclosed location.

7.caption:
Handler Eric Kenas uses hand gestures with a
 dolphin. The Navy has trained marine mammals, including belugas like 
Noc, for 50 years.

8.caption:
Hull Technician Fireman Stefan 
Gingerich gives positive reinforcement during a mine countermeasure 
exercise in the Pacific.

9.caption:
Navy Diver Second Class Michael Gerstel rewards a
 bottlenose dolphin during an annual training exercise in Little Creek, 
Virginia.

10.caption:
Michael Gerstel works with a cetacean assigned to
 the Marine Mammal Company of Explosive Ordnance Disposal Mobile 
Unit.

11.caption:
The Navy unit uses the marine mammals because 
they can locate and mark mines using their built-in sonar 
capabilities.

12.caption:
Another dolphin gets training with the unit’s 
Christopher Burgess in 2013 in Point Loma, California, before a 
nighttime exercise.

3209855247.resolved_title:

3209855247.excerpt:
How we evolved to read is a story of one creative 
species. The Chinese artist Xu Bing has long experimented to stunning 
effect with the limits of the written form. Last year I visited the 
Centre del Carme in Valencia, Spain, to see a retrospective of his 
work.

2.caption:
BOOKKEEPING: This example of ancient 
cuneiform writing dates back to the Bronze Age. Irving Finkel of the 
British Museum says “a kind of administrative responsibility produced 
the first stumbling attempt at writing and then eventually a proper 
fluent script.”

3.caption:
WRITE ON: Writing arose at different places around the 
globe, diverging from pictographic to alphabetic symbols. But when we 
look deep inside the brain, it turns out people everywhere write and 
read in remarkably similar ways.

country’s population.

In the mind’s eye of many people, Japan is a land of 
tranquil Zen gardens, serene temples, and exquisite tea ceremonies. Both
 traditional and contemporary Japanese architecture, books and magazines
 are the envy of designers worldwide.
